title-group.article-title: Effect of ethylene vinyl acetate on physico-mechanical and thermal properties of polypropylene and starch biocomposites

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Research and Development, Central Institute of Plastics Engineering and Technology (CIPET), Vatva, Ahmedabad, Gujarat, India
2Corporate Office, Central Institute of Plastics Engineering and Technology (CIPET), Guindy, Chennai, Tamilnadu, India

author-notes.corresp: B. Ramaraj, Department of Research and Development, Central Institute of Plastics Engineering and Technology (CIPET), 630 Phase IV, GIDC, Vatva, Ahmedabad 382445, Gujarat, India Email: ramaraj_rmrj@yahoo.co.in

abstract.p: The aim of this research is to investigate the effects of ethylene vinyl acetate (EVA) as compatibilizer on physico-mechanical and thermal properties of polypropylene (PP)/starch composites. PP/starch composites were prepared by the extrusion of PP resin with potato starch in co-rotating twin-screw extruder by varying starch content from 5 to 20%, where the EVA content was 10 wt% based upon potato starch. It was found that with the increase in starch content from 0 to 20% in the PP matrix, the tensile elongation increased from 19.77 to 32.0%, moisture content increased from 0.013 to 0.062%, water absorption increased from 0.035 to 0.181% and density increased from 0.912 to 0.985 g/cm3, however, the tensile, flexural and impact properties, Rockwell hardness, melt flow index and vicat softening point were found to decrease linearly. Similarly, the incorporation of starch with EVA has reduced the melting temperature of PP matrix from 162.3 to 158.55°C, the heat of fusion (▵H f) of PP matrix decreased from 66.52 to 27.05 J/g and so is the percentage crystallization, decreased from 31.83 to 21.45% with increase in starch content from 0 to 20 wt% in the PP matrix.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Polypropylene (PP) is a synthetic thermoplastic that offers a combination of outstanding physical, mechanical, thermal, electrical and chemical properties and widely used in automobile, electrical equipments, furniture and packaging industries. The market size of PP is currently 100 billion pounds globally. 1 And the use of this material has accelerated to the extent that the disposal has become increasingly difficult, because PP is resistant to microbial attack and biodegradation. This gives rise to serious environmental effects allied with the accumulation of plastic products. 2 To initiate microbial attack and accelerate biodegradation, biodegradable natural fillers such as starch was incorporated into the polyolefin matrix. Incorporation of starch into a polyolefin matrix was proposed by Griffin 3,4 as an effective means of accelerating the deterioration of plastics under biotic environmental exposure conditions. The inclusion of starch, a readily biodegradable biopolymer, into the synthetic polymer is believed to result in rapid enzymatic hydrolysis of starch under biotic exposure condition, leading to a void-containing matrix. The reduced mechanical integrity of the ensuing void-containing matrix leads to its facile deterioration, and perhaps even promotes subsequent biodegradation of the synthetic polymer, due to the increased surface area available for interaction with microorganisms.

Starch is unique among carbohydrates because it occurs naturally as discrete particles called granules. 5 The granules are the primary means of energy storage in green plants over long periods of time, and the shape and size of the granules depend on their origin. The important sources of starch are wheat, potato, rice, tapioca and corn. Potato starch is obtained from the tuber of Solanum tuberosum L, and it is a very fine white powder practically insoluble in cold water and in alcohol. Potato starch does not contain starch grains of any other origin. Potatoes are the world’s fourth largest food crop, following rice, wheat and maize. China is now the world’s largest potato producing country, and nearly a third of the world’s potatoes are harvested in China and India. The predominant form of this carbohydrate is starch. Starch has drawn a lot of attention in the preparation of biodegradable plastics. It is abundantly produced by photosynthetic plants and, therefore, is renewable and cheap. The addition of starch to synthetic plastics is known to enhance the biodegradability.

It is reported that tensile properties of the PP/sago starch blends decreased with increasing sago starch content even though sago starch granules were well dispersed in the PP matrix. 6 The reduction in tensile property may be due to the incompatibility and poor interfacial adhesion due to the differences in the polarity and hydrophilicity of these two phases—PP and starch. These problems, however, can be overcome using a compatibilizer that can react with the hydroxyl group of starch and form hydrogen bonds or covalent bonds with synthetic polymers. Maleated PP is one such material used as a compatibilizer and found to show improved tensile strength. 7 Ethylene-co-acrylic acid copolymer is another most frequently used compatibilizer in starch/polyolefin blends. Recently, Prinos et al., 2 Otey and Westhoff 8 and Willet 9 studied a series of low-density polyethylene blends with plasticized starch and granular starch and used ethylene vinyl acetate (EVA) copolymer as a compatibilizer.

With the ongoing research efforts aimed at the preparation and evaluation of biodegradable polymer composites, 10
–13 this work aims to utilize the EVA as compatibilizer and to study its effects on physico-mechanical and thermal properties of PP and starch composites. In today’s environmentally focused society, the demand for cost effective, environmental friendly materials continues to increase. The driving force behind the use of the starch is its low cost, annually renewable resource utilization and environmental benefits.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: PP injection grade H200MK obtained from Reliance Industries Limited, Mumbai, India, was used as a polymer matrix. Its melt flow index (MFI) and density as reported by the manufacturer were 20 g/10 min and 0.919 g/cm3, respectively. EVA with 18% vinyl acetate content was obtained from Taiwan and used as received. The potato starch granules (insoluble) of 60 mesh size with 0.30% sulphated ash obtained from M/S S D Fine-Chem Limited, Mumbai, India, was used as the filler. And xylene (sulphur free, boiling range 137–144°C supplied by M/S S D Fine-Chem Limited, Mumbai, India) was used as the solvent for EVA.

sec.title: Preparation of starch master batch
sec.p: In a batch, 90 g of starch powder was taken in 100 ml of xylene (sulphur free) and heated on hot plate under stirring in boiling condition until it became a complete solution and xylene was added to maintain fluid condition. To this solution 10 g of EVA granules were added under constant stirring and boiling until it dissolved completely. After complete dissolution, this solution was poured into a glass mould for solvent evaporation. After 2 days of solvent evaporation, the thick sheet thus obtained was cut into small flakes and dried in an air circulating oven at 50°C for 6 h to remove any volatile matter. This oven-dried starch master batch was used for compounding with PP granules.

sec.title: Compounding and specimen preparation
sec.p: The EVA flakes containing 90% starch was mixed with PP granules and extruded in a twin-screw extruder (JSW 30α, Japan) with a length-to-diameter ratio (L/D ratio) of 36/1 in the temperature range of 170–230°C. The extrudate strands were granulated and stored in sealed packs containing desiccant. Four level of starch loading (5, 10, 15 and 20 wt%) were designed in sample preparation. Tensile, flexural, izod, Rockwell hardness and water absorption specimens were prepared using an ENGEL 80 automatic injection moulding machine with 50 ton clamping pressure in the temperature range of 180–215°C and an injection pressure of 90 bars. After moulding, the test specimens were conditioned at 23 ± 2°C and 50 ± 5% relative humidity for 24 h according to American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) D 618 before testing.

sec.title: Testing methods
sec.p: Tensile and flexural strength tests were carried out as per ASTM D 638 and ASTM D 790, respectively, on universal testing machine (Lloyds, LR 100 K, UK). Izod impact strength tests were carried out as per ASTM D 256 A on RESIL IMPACTOR (CEAST, Italy). Vicat softening point (VSP) test was carried out as per ASTM D 1525 test method on HDT-VICAT Junior (CEAST, Italy). MFI analysis of various formulations was measured using extrudate pellets on melt flow indexer (Lloyds melt flow index tester, Type 7273) at 190°C and at 2.16 kg load as per ASTM D 1238. Rockwell hardness was measured using EIE HARDNESS TESTER [EIE Instruments Pvt Ltd, Ahmedabad, Gujarat, India]. Density was measured using a Mettler PM200 [Mettler Toledo India pvt ltd, Mumbai, India] electronic weighing balance as per ATM D 792 displacement method.

sec.title: Measurement of moisture and water absorption
sec.p: The moisture absorption of PP and its starch composites were measured using injection moulded 50 mm disc specimens. The discs were dried in a hot air oven at 80°C for 24 h and placed in an enclosure containing distilled water. The discs were then removed after 24 h to determine the weight change or moisture absorption. The moisture absorption was calculated from the difference in the initial and dry weight of the sample.

Similarly water absorption of PP and its starch composites were measured using injection moulded 50 mm disc specimens as per ASTM D 570. The discs were dried in a hot air oven at 80°C for 24 h and placed inside the beaker containing distilled water. The discs were then removed after 24 h to determine the weight change or water absorption. The water absorption was calculated from the difference in the initial and dry weight of the sample according to equation (1). Three specimens were measured for each sample and the results were averaged to obtain a mean value.

sec.title: Thermal analysis by differential scanning calorimetric
sec.p:
Differential scanning calorimeter (DSC; Perkin-Elmer Diamond DSC) was employed to characterize the thermal properties of the PP/potato starch composites. A sample size with an average weight of 8.50 mg encapsulated in a hermetically sealed aluminium pan was prepared for each composite sample. A series of PP/starch composites with 0, 5, 10, 15 and 20 wt% starch contents designated as A, B, C, D and E were used for the analysis. The samples were heated from ambient to 200°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min under nitrogen atmosphere. The melting temperature (T m) and heat of fusion (▵H f) of the composite samples were determined from the peak maximum and the area under the peak, respectively. The degree of crystallinity of PP/potato starch biocomposites and the PP phase was calculated using the following equation 14
–18

where ▵H f is the latent heat of fusion of the composite sample, ▵H f100 is the latent heat of fusion of a PP with 100% crystallinity (207.1 J/g) and W is the weight fraction of PP in the composite. The heat of fusion is corrected by taking into account only the PP content in the composite. 19

sec.title: Thermal analysis by thermogravimetry
sec.p: A Perkin-Elmer Pyris 1 TGA Thermogravimetric system, with a microprocessor-driven temperature control unit, was used for thermogravimetric analysis. A series of PP/starch composites with 0, 5, 10, 15 and 20 wt% of starch contents designated as A, B, C, D and E were used for the analysis. TGA samples were prepared by cutting injection moulded test specimens into small pieces of approximately 10–13 mg and used in this study. The sample pan was placed in the balance system in equipment and the temperature was raised from 50 to 600°C at a heating rate of 20°C/min in nitrogen atmosphere. The weight of the sample pan was continuously recorded as a function of the temperature.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
The incorporation of starch as a filler, as a method of producing biodegradable polymer composite is pioneered by Griffin 2,3 and expanded by many others. 6
–9 It is found that the addition of granular starch into polyolefins follow the general trend of filler effect on polymers, that is the mechanical properties decrease as the starch content increased. The problems associated with the reduction in mechanical strength are (a) the hydrophilicity of starch, which renders poor adhesion with hydrophobic polymer and (b) degradation of starch during melt processing when it comes in contact with processing machine surface, because the starch granules undergoes degradation before its melting. To improve the compatibility between the potato starch and PP, and to avoid the degradation of starch powder during processing, starch powder loaded EVA matrix was used for compounding and extrusion. The primary role of EVA is to act as compatibilizer to reduce the interfacial energy and thereby improve the mechanical strength of polymer matrix. Since EVA is elastomeric in nature and tolerates 90% starch loading, 90% starch loaded EVA was cast as sheet and made into flakes and melt blended with PP granules. Since starch loaded EVA matrix was in the from of flakes, this methodology solves three problems, first, starch powder is not directly in contact with processing machine surface, so there is no thermal degradation of starch; second, the feeding problem associated with starch powder and PP granules is removed and finally the EVA acts as compatiblizer between hydrophobic PP matrix and hydrophilic starch granules.

sec.title: Tensile and flexural properties of PP/starch composites.
sec.p:
The tensile and flexural properties of PP and its composites at different starch contents are given in Table 1. This shows that the tensile strength results decreased from 42.63 to 22.50 MPa, whereas the tensile elongation increased from 19.77 to 32.00%. This reveals that incorporation of potato starch had reduced the tensile strength but increased the elongation. Incorporation of starch into PP matrix has reduced tensile strength in all compositions, regardless of the existence of compatiblizer. This is a generally observed phenomenon in starch filler polymers because of the presence of starch that does not contribute to the mechanical properties of the composites and has been observed in many studies. 3
–6 However, the main purpose of this work is to test the effect of EVA as compatibilizer on the mechanical properties of PP/starch blends. The reduction in tensile strength may be due to the weakness of interfacial adhesion as well as the elastomeric nature of compatibilizer—EVA. This theory is supported by an increase in tensile elongation from 19.77 to 32%. The reduction in tensile strength is a general phenomena observed in thermoplastics filled with natural filler, 20 –22 as filler loading increased, thereby increasing the interfacial area, worsening interfacial bonding between the filler and the matrix, where the tensile strength and elongation decreased as the starch addition increases. 23,24 However, here the tensile elongation increased due to the elastomeric nature of the compatibilizer used.

caption.p: Effect of EVA and starch on tensile and flexural properties of PP composites

fn.p: EVA: ethylene vinyl acetate; PP: polypropylene.

sec.p:
Despite the interest in starch as biodegradable filler, little has been done to understand the properties of starch/synthetic polymer composites in terms of theories of composite properties. Several theories of the dependence of composite properties on filler-volume fraction ‘Φ’ and geometry have been developed. Nicolais and Narkis 25 developed a geometric model for the tensile (yield) strength ‘σ’ of a composite with uniformly distributed spherical filler particles of equal radius
2
σ
c
=
σ
o
( 1 − 1.21
Φ
2
/
3
)

The subscripts ‘c’ and ‘o’ represent the composite and the matrix polymer, respectively. This model is based on the assumption that the decrease in tensile strength is due to the reduction in effective cross-sectional area caused by the spherical filler particles. No adhesion between the matrix and the filler particle is assumed. Several composite systems have been found to follow equation (2). 26,27

The experimental and the theoretical (the tensile values calculated based on equation (2)) tensile strength values are plotted against the volume fraction of starch and shown in Figure 1. It is seen from the graph that the difference between theoretical and experimental values decreases with an increase in the starch content. This may be due to the effect of EVA as a compatibilizer between starch powder and PP.

caption.p: Effect of ethylene vinyl acetate (EVA) and starch on tensile strength of polypropylene (PP) composites.

sec.p:
Nielsen 28,29 derived the following relationship between elongation and volume fraction of the filler ‘Φ’ 3
ϵ

( 1 −
Φ
1
/
3
)
where ‘∊ c’ is the elongation to break (or yield) of the composite and ‘∊o’ is the corresponding elongation of the unfilled polymer matrix. Perfect adhesion between polymer matrix and filler is assumed in this model. The fundamental mechanism of this model is the requirement the polymer matrix confined between two particles must undergo a larger strain than the macroscopic strain because the rigid filler particles do not elongate. Equation (3) has been shown to describe the behaviour of some glass bead filled composites. 30,31 The tensile elongation of PP calculated using equation (3) for PP/starch composites and the experimental results are plotted against the volume fraction of starch in Figure 2. It is seen from the graph that theoretical values decrease, while the experimental values increase progressively underlining the fact that it does not follow the model in any way. This may be because the elastomeric nature of compatibilizer has more important role than its compatibility role between starch and PP.

caption.p: Effects of ethylene vinyl acetate (EVA) and starch on tensile elongation of polypropylene (PP) composites.

sec.p: While the incorporation of potato starch had reduced the tensile strength and increased the elongation at break, the tensile modulus is decreased from 845.58 to 666.89 MPa, similarly the flexural strength decreased from 43.44 to 29.18 MPa and flexural modulus decreased from 1355 to 657 MPa as the starch content increased from 0 to 20% as shown in Table 1. This may be due to the fact that EVA is elastomeric and does not have sufficient compatibilizing effect between PP and starch. As the starch content increases, the EVA content also increases linearly, thereby reducing the mechanical properties. The material became less rigid and flexible than the material without starch. But starch granules may be stiffer than the PP matrix in which they are dispersed. 32

sec.title: Impact strength of PP/starch composites
sec.p: The notched and unnotched izod impact strengths of composites at different filler loadings are shown in Figure 3. Both notched and unnotched izod impact strengths of composites decreased with increase in starch content. In case of notched sample, the impact strength decreased from 33.07 to 23.28 J/m, with increasing amount of starch filler. For unnotched samples, the impact strength decreased from 501.37 to 271.07 J/m. As can be seen in Figure 3, unnotched izod impact energies were considerably larger than notched izod impact energies. This is due to the different fracture process for notched and unnotched samples. The unnotched impact behaviour is controlled to a considerable extent by fracture initiation process that, in turn, is controlled by stress concentration at defects in the system. Notched impact behaviour, meanwhile, is controlled to a greater extent by factors affecting the propagation of the fracture initiated at the predominating stress concentration at the notched tip. In other words, unnotched izod impact energies are a measure of not only crack propagation but also crack initiation. The unnotched composite samples showed significantly high impact strength (501.37 J/m) as compared to the notched, which drastically decreased with increasing filler from 501.37 to 277.07 J/m. The notched tip, which is the stress concentrating point, causes relatively low impact strength in the notched sample, thereby allowing the crack to propagate easily, and the same effect appeared at the filler–matrix interfacial area in the filler contained unnotched sample.

caption.p: Effects of ethylene vinyl acetate (EVA) and starch on izod impact strength of polypropylene (PP) composites.

sec.title: Moisture, water absorption, density and hardness of PP/starch composites
sec.p: The measured properties such as moisture and water absorption and density of PP/starch composites are given in Table 2. It is seen from the table, the moisture absorption of PP composite increased from 0.013 to 0.062% and water absorption increased from 0.035 to 0.181% with increase in starch content from 0 to 20%. It has been found that the resistance of conventional plastics against microorganisms is primarily owing to their relative impermeability of water or moisture. In other words, moisture absorption of the plastic is also a key factor to promote or facilitate the biodegradation rate. As expected, moisture absorption increased with increasing starch content. Because of its hydrophilic nature, potato starch absorbs moisture from the atmosphere. Its moisture absorption at equilibrium is almost 15%. Moisture absorption of the pure PP disc was almost 0%, whereas for the PP/potato starch composite, their moisture absorption increased as the amount of potato starch increased. These results ensure that potato starch is more hydrophilic than PP, leading to an enhancement of hydrogen bond formation between hydroxyl groups in the starch and moisture. Since starch is a highly water absorbing material compared to PP, the starch composites are expected to have a higher water absorption with a proportionate increase in starch content. But it is observed from Table 2 that there is only a marginal increase (0.035–0.181%) in water absorption. This may be due to the fact that the starch granules are encapsulated by PP matrix and hence, starch granules are not exposed to the surface to have higher water absorption.

caption.p: Effect of EVA and starch on moisture, water absorption and density of PP composites

fn.p: EVA: ethylene vinyl acetate; PP: polypropylene.

sec.p: In case of density (Table 2), the density of PP increased from 0.912 to 0.985 g/cm3 with increase in starch content from 0 to 20 wt%. The increases in density may be due to the higher density of the starch filler (1.575 g/cm3). 33 We also calculated the densities by volume additivity method, which states that d = w 1 d 1 + w 2 d 2, where d is the density of the blend, w 1 and w 2 are the weight fractions of the constituents and d 1 and d 2 are the corresponding densities. The plot of density versus starch composition for the PP/starch composites are shown in Figure 4, which shows the density of the composite increased linearly with increase in starch content. Further, actual density values of these composites are much lesser than that of its theoretical values calculated by volume additivity principle. The difference in density may be due to the incompatibility and microvoid formation, poor interfacial adhesion or phase separation between PP and starch.

caption.p: Effects of ethylene vinyl acetate (EVA) and starch on density of polypropylene (PP) composites.

sec.p: The hardness of the PP and its composites with starch was measured using a Rockwell hardness and given in Table 3. The surface hardness decreases from 102 to 85 with increase in starch content. This may again be due to the poor interfacial adhesion, or phase separation between PP and starch in addition to the elastomeric effect of the EVA.

caption.p: Effect of EVA and starch on surface hardness, melt flow index and vicat softening point of PP composites

fn.p: EVA: ethylene vinyl acetate; PP: polypropylene.

sec.title: MFI and vicat softening point
sec.p: Table 3 shows that the MFI values of PP/starch composites decreased from 19.83 to 13.80 g/10 min as the starch content increased from 0 to 20 wt%. The MFI, a measure roughly of the inverse of its viscosity, decreased with the addition of starch, making the viscosity increase. Reduction in MFI values indicates the viscosity of composite increased. This is similar to most filled thermoplastic and in agreement with that reported by the researchers before, stating that the MFI of starch composite decreased as the filler loading increased. 23 The reduction may be due to the starch granules that can still retain their shape and function as rigid particulate fillers when processed. When the starch content increases, the interaction among the granules was increased; subsequently the spaces between particle–particle became small. If the particle–particle interactions are stronger than particle–matrix interaction, agglomeration of particles may occur and result in the immobilization of more matrix molecules. The matrix molecules become trap in filler particles as the size of agglomerates increases and flows of matrix have been confined. Decrease in MFI is also due to the fact that starch particles are more viscous than PP. This can be observed from the data above; MFI of neat PP is higher than PP/starch.

The VSP is one of the methods used to assess the elevated temperature performance of plastics. From Table 3, it is noticed that the VSP of virgin PP is 147.6°C and it is reduced to 145.5°C. The observed reduction in VSP values may be due to the incompatibility between starch and PP as well as the presence of elastomeric EVA.

sec.title: DSC analysis of PP/starch composites
sec.p: The thermal properties of PP/starch composite samples were investigated by DSC to analyze the effect of starch and EVA content on melting temperature (T m), heat-of-fusion and crystallinity of PP matrix. The DSC thermograms of PP and PP/starch composite samples are shown in Figure 5 and the results are summarized in Table 4. The melting temperature (T m) of PP decreased from 162.3 to 158.55°C with increase in starch contents from 0 to 20 wt% (Figure 5 and Table 4). This decrease in melting temperature might be related to a decrease in the crystallinity of the sample and perfection of the crystal structure due to the inclusion of the filler in the crystalline regions of PP matrix.

caption.p: Differential scanning calorimetric (DSC) traces of polypropylene (PP) and starch composites.
Effect of EVA and starch on melting temperature, heat of fusion and percentage of crystallization of PP composites

fn.p: EVA: ethylene vinyl acetate; PP: polypropylene.

sec.p: Degree of crystallinity of PP and its composites is estimated by heat-of-fusion measurements using DSC and shown in Table 4. The estimation of the degree of crystallinity is very significant to understand the changes in the structural characteristics induced by starch and EVA. To check whether the filler is located in the crystalline zones of the composite material, this study reports the dependence of the melting enthalpy and the degree of crystallinity on the filler content. Table 4 shows the variation in melting enthalpy as a function of the composition as measured by DSC. The heat of fusion (▵H f) of PP matrix decreased from 66.52 to 27.05 J/g and so the percentage crystallization decreased from 31.83 to 21.45%, with increase in starch content from 0 to 20 wt% in the PP matrix. Apparently the value of melting enthalpy decreases gradually with increase in starch content, indicating decrease in crystallinity. All the results indicate that the starch granules and EVA disturbed the crystalline regions of PP matrix. The crystalline order of PP matrix is broken as a consequence of the formation of filler aggregates.

sec.title: Thermogravimetric analysis of PP/starch composites
sec.p: Typical TGA traces obtained for virgin PP and starch are shown in Figure 6. As can be seen from Figure 6, the initial weight loss for starch began at approximately 55°C and reached a constant weight plateau after losing 15% of its initial weight. This weight loss corresponds to the loss of the moisture content from the potato starch. At 280°C, the potato starch began to degrade; this was defined as the degradation temperature of potato starch. After 300°C, starch shows more than 20% residues, it is around 17.4% at 496°C, whereas the virgin PP shows only a negligible weight loss below 380°C (Figure 6 and Table 5). At 496°C, it does not show any residue due to complete decomposition. The TGA thermograms of PP/starch composites containing 5, 10, 15 and 20% starch are labelled as B, C, D and E and are shown in Figure 7, which show that with an increase in starch content the thermal weight loss increases proportionately with an increase in residual content at 496°C (Table 5). Data generally showed a distinct and consistent nonreversible loss in weight, attributed to the pyrolysis of starch in the temperature interval of 280–350°C. Obviously, the PP/starch composites degraded in two stages (Figure 7). The first one around 280–350°C is due to starch decomposition and the second one around 350–480°C for PP. The second stage of thermal decomposition began around 454°C, with the weight decreasing rapidly at 470°C.

caption.p: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) traces of polypropylene (PP) and starch composites.
Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) traces of polypropylene (PP)/starch composites.
Effect of starch on thermal stability of PP composites

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: With the objective to study the effect of EVA as a compatibilizer on the physicomechanical properties, PP/starch composites were prepared by varying starch content from 5 to 20% in the presence of EVA. It was found that with increase in starch content from 0 to 20% in the PP matrix, the tensile elongation increased from 19.77 to 32.0%, moisture content increased from 0.013 to 0.062%, water absorption increased from 0.035 to 0.181% and density increased from 0.9121 to 0.9851 g/cm3. DSC results reveal reduction in melting temperature, heat of fusion and percentage of crystallization of PP with increase in starch content. Similarly, TGA traces display enhanced thermal degradability of PP as the starch content increases. The decrease in tensile and flexural properties with addition of starch filler to PP matrix follows the general trend of filler effects on polymer matrix despite the presence of EVA as compatibilizer. So, it is reasonable to conclude that EVA is not a right choice material for PP/starch composites. However, the main purpose of this work is to study the effect of starch on the mechanical and thermal properties of the PP matrix. The utilization of starch in the PP matrix may reduce the cost as well as bring environmental benefits.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
